The highly effective vaccine is available for routine use in adults and children older than 9 months
15 . However, during epidemics the vaccine is often used in children from 6 months of age and in pregnant or lactating women
16 . The YF vaccine is a freeze-dried preparation of the live attenuated YF virus strain 17D that was developed in 1937 and now produced by four WHO-prequalified vaccine manufacturers using sub-strains of 17D (see Table 1)
17, 18 . The seed virus, derived from the 17D strain, is inoculated into specific-pathogen-free chicken embryonated eggs and after 3–4 days the embryos are aseptically harvested, homogenized and centrifuged to produce bulk vaccine before stabilizing the product. This process is laborious and current capacity to produce increased stock in response to epidemics is limited
7, 15, 19– 21 .
